description: A small, bright green parrot with a greyish breast and cheeks. They are the only parrot species that builds its own nest out of sticks rather than nesting in a cavity.
temperament: Confident, social, and comical. Quakers are known for their big personalities and can be very cuddly. They are also known for being territorial about their cages.
loudness: Loud. They are prone to chattering and squawking and can be quite noisy, especially when they hear sounds like the phone ringing or the vacuum cleaner.
vocalization: Excellent talkers. Many Quakers learn to speak very clearly and can accumulate a large vocabulary.
dietaryNeeds: A pelleted diet with fresh vegetables and some fruit. They are prone to fatty liver disease, so a low-fat diet is very important.
healthPointers: Hardy and adaptable, with a lifespan of 20-30 years. Prone to fatty liver disease and feather plucking if they become bored or are on a poor diet. They are illegal to own in some states due to fears of them establishing feral colonies.
housing: Can be challenging for apartments due to their noise level. A minimum cage size of 20"W x 20"D x 24"H is recommended.
